appealReceived.content: We have told the DWP that you want to appeal against their decision. They have to provide a written response before {{date | formatDate}} We will contact you and explain the next steps when they have replied.

dwpRespond.heading: DWP response
content: We have told the DWP you wanted to appeal against their decision on your claim for PIP benefit. They have now responded and told us they have not changed their decision. They should have sent you a copy of their response in the post.
We are now in the process of booking a hearing for your appeal. We’ll contact you within 6 weeks to tell you when and where your hearing is.

claimExpenses.title: Claiming expenses to attend your hearing
claimExpenses.content: You may be able to claim back some of the money you spend on attending your hearing.

content: You should use public transport where possible. Keep your travel tickets and bring them with you to your hearing. You’ll be given a claim form to fill out by the tribunal clerk.

If you have a health condition or disability which means you can’t get yourself to the hearing then you might be able to claim for a taxi. You’ll need to get authorisation first by phoning 0300 123 1142.

provide.title: Providing evidence to support your appeal
provide.content: Evidence is anything that supports your appeal. It could be medical records, letters or documents. What you say at the hearing is also classed as evidence. It all helps the tribunal understand the facts of your appeal.

medicalEvidence.heading: Medical evidence
content: This is the most common and useful form of evidence. Medical evidence helps the tribunal understand your condition and how it affects your life.
As a patient, you have a right to a copy of your medical records. You’ll need to request them from your doctor as early as possible in your appeal. Only request records going back 2 years.

You may also have other medical evidence which is not included in your medical records. For example a letter from a consultant, physiotherapist or mental health worker. Submit these too, if they are relevant to your condition at the time of receiving your decision from the DWP.

You’ll need to send evidence to the tribunal as early as possible. If you submit evidence too close to your hearing, it may be delayed to a different day because there hasn’t been enough time to review it.
Please note that your doctor or consultant may charge you for your medical records. We can’t reimburse you for this.

oralEvidence.heading: Oral evidence
content: What you or anyone else says on your behalf at the hearing is classed as oral evidence. If you have a carer or someone who supports you in the home, you might want to invite them to come and tell the tribunal about your condition.
You should check the person is happy with talking at your hearing and available on the day.

expectations.title: What to expect at your hearing
expectations.link: Find out what your hearing is going to be like
expectations.content: Your hearing is an opportunity for you to explain your case and get a decision on your benefit appeal. The tribunal is independent from the DWP and will listen to both sides of the dispute before making a decision.

whenYouArrive.heading: When you arrive
whenYouArrive.content: You’ll be greeted by a tribunal clerk. They’ll take care of you at the hearing venue and answer any questions you may have. You’ll then sit in a waiting area until your hearing begins.

theHearingRoom.heading: The hearing room
theHearingRoom.content: The tribunal clerk will take you into a room for your hearing. It’s more like a meeting room than a courtroom. The judge will be sat behind a table and you’ll be invited to sit opposite him or her. If you have someone to support you or give evidence, they’ll sit next to you.

image.content: A typical PIP benefit appeal hearing. The judge sits in the middle. A doctor and a disability expert sits either side.

peopleAtHearing.heading: The people at your hearing
content: The tribunal is made up of a panel of people who together make a decision on your appeal.
The judge runs the hearing. They’ll explain how the hearing works and will write notes throughout. This is to create a record of the hearing.

There’ll also be a doctor and a disability expert either side of the judge. They provide medical and disability advice. In Employment Support Allowance (ESA) appeals there’ll just be a doctor with the judge.

dwp.heading: The DWP
content: A representative from the DWP may also be there. They are not on the panel and are there to speak on behalf of the DWP. They are not the person who made the decision on your benefits.

duringHearing.heading: During your hearing
content: The judge and the other panel members will ask you some straightforward questions. They’re trying to understand how your condition affects your life. They may ask how you cope with certain tasks or what types of of things you need help with.

They may also ask you questions that relate to the evidence you or the DWP have provided. Sometimes the panel will need more evidence or information to help them make a decision. It’s important that you submit all your evidence well before the hearing so they have time to review it. Otherwise they may have to postpone the hearing to a different day.

gettingDecision.heading: Getting a decision
content: You’ll be asked to wait outside while the panel members discuss your appeal. You’ll then be asked back into the room to be told the decision.
The judge will explain whether you are entitled to the benefit in question and if so, at what level.
Sometimes the tribunal may need more time to make a decision. Your decision will be posted to you in that case.

hearingDetails.interpretersBookedByUs: Only interpreters booked by us can translate for you at the hearing.
hearingDetails.incorrect: If anything above is incorrect or you cannot attend, call us on 0300 123 1142

pleaseNote.heading: Please note
content: You can bring people to support you at your hearing. For example family, friends or a support worker. There will be a limit to the number of people you can take into the hearing room because of space.
Children are allowed in the waiting area but not in the hearing room. You’ll need to bring someone to supervise them while you’re in the hearing.
Bring any documents relating to your appeal to the hearing. For example letters or evidence we or the DWP have sent you.
